conversation.message: Dear Nursery_C admissions team, I’m Parent_E and I would like to formally apply for your available place. Nursery_C is my first-choice nursery because its environment and approach are the best fit for our family. If offered a spot, I will accept promptly and commit to enrolling. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is Nursery_C. Although Nursery_C ranks me 4th (behind Parents B, C, and D), applying immediately maximizes my chance before their applications potentially fill the single seat. If rejected, I can pivot quickly to my next choices (Nursery_D, then Nursery_A where I have top priority).

conversation.message:
Dear Parent_E,

Thank you for your application and for your strong interest in Nursery_C. After reviewing current demand and our placement priorities, we’re not able to offer you the place at this time.

We appreciate you considering Nursery_C and wish you the very best with your other nursery options.
conversation.thought: As Nursery_C, my true priority is Parent_B > Parent_C > Parent_D > Parent_E > Parent_A. I currently have an [APPLY] from Parent_E, who is only 4th on my list. In round 1, higher-priority parents (B/C/D) are likely to apply elsewhere first (B: A then B then C; C: B then C; D: B then C), but Nursery_C is the 3rd choice for Parent_B and 2nd for Parents_C and D, so there is a meaningful chance they approach me in later rounds if rejected elsewhere. Since accepting Parent_E now would fill my only seat and prevent matching with a higher-priority parent later, the optimal strategy to maximize my outcome is to reject Parent_E at this stage and keep capacity available for B/C/D.

conversation.message: Dear Nursery_B Admissions Team, I’m Parent_D and Nursery_B is my first-choice nursery. We value your program and community and would be ready to accept an offer promptly if selected. Thank you for considering my application.

Additionally, Parent_E (my top choice) has not applied to me this round and likely targets Nursery_C first, so waiting is risky; the best available option now is Parent_C. Therefore, I should reject Parent_D to preserve the slot for a higher-priority parent.
